On August 5, 2014, our son John Crawford III was killed by police while 
shopping at a Wal-mart in Beavercreek, Ohio. At the time of his shooting, 
our son was on his cell phone talking with LeeCee Johnson, the mother of 
his two children.
 
Ohio State Attorney General Mike DeWine showed us the Wal-Mart surveillance 
footage. After viewing it, we know for certain that our son did nothing 
wrong. He was simply shopping. He'd picked up a toy rifle and was carrying 
it with the barrel pointed at the floor. Our son had no opportunity to put 
the toy down before he was shot on sight by a policeman.
We call on the U.S. Justice Department to open a civil rights investigation 
of this unjustified police shooting. We also demand that Mr. DeWine release 
the video of our son's murder, particularly since authorities have released 
other material recordings, such as the 911 call and police dash camera 
footage.
We are concerned with the slow pace of the investigation and worry that the 
state of Ohio is stalling. The grand jury had been scheduled to convene on 
September 3rd but was postponed to Sept. 22nd.
We are also concerned that Sgt. David Darkow, one of two officers involved 
in Crawford's killing, has returned to active police duty.
We are further concerned that the other officer, Sean Williams, who remains 
on administrative leave was also involved in a 2010 fatal shooting. He was 
never prosecuted in that case.
LeeCee was with us at the time John was killed. When she realized what was 
happening, she placed her call with John on speaker. We all listened to 
John die. He was only 22.
We believe a federal investigation will provide us with a fair and 
transparent review of the facts surrounding our son's death. Please join us 
in calling on Attorney General Eric Holder to open a U.S. Justice 
Department investigation into our son's murder and prosecute the officer 
who is responsible for the shooting and killing of John Crawford III.

Part of the problem is that a large number of people don't understand that 
it is perfectly legal for someone to shoot someone who is unarmed under 
some circumstances. 

http://legalinsurrection.com/2014/08/why-use-of-a-gun-can-be-lawful-even-against-an-unarmed-person//#more

"One of the most common laments to come out of Ferguson these last days has 
been that surely it was outrageous for Office Darren Wilson to use his 
service pistol to shoot an “unarmed” Mike Brown. (Earlier iterations of 
this narrative went further in their misinformation, describing the 
18-year-old 6’4″ 292 pound Brown as a “kid” or “child,” as well as 
falsely claiming that Wilson shot Brown in the back, but such 
misinformation falls outside the scope of this post.) Similar arguments 
were made in the context of the shooting by George Zimmerman of the 
“unarmed” Trayvon Martin.

The notion that a defender may use a firearm in self-defense only if they 
themselves are faced with a firearm is entertainingly naive, but has no 
basis in actual law, nor in common sense.

In the eyes of the law a gun is not some magical talisman of power, it is 
merely one of perhaps an infinite number of means of exerting force. 
Legally speaking the law tends to divide force into two broad buckets: 
non-deadly force and deadly force. There is some stratification in the 
context of non-deadly force–a poke to the chest is not the same degree of 
non-deadly force as a punch to the face–but really none whatever in the 
context of deadly force. Deadly force is simply deadly force. For purposes 
of conciseness, I limit this discussion to cases in which deadly force is 
involved, as was the case in both Ferguson and Zimmerman."﻿
